Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The timestamp, activity, department, patient age, and gender from the events were analyzed to associate them with patients and group them into logical sequences based on medical workflows, such as registration preceding triage and discharge concluding a case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Registration for ER (events 1 and 2) was identified as the starting step for Case 1 and Case 2, respectively, based on patient attributes and department. Similarly, Case 3 was identified to start directly in the Surgery department with event 3.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: It was inferred that triage processes follow registrations within the same department. Therefore, event 4 was linked to Case 1 (patient A) and event 5 to Case 2 (patient B).

Name: Validation - PE
Text: The correctness of patient associations was cross-checked by comparing attributes like patient age and gender across events, ensuring that no patient was assigned to multiple overlapping cases.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: For Case 3's patient (28-year-old male), events in the Surgery department (e.g., X-ray, surgery preparation) were assumed to be part of their treatment path, even without explicit ER triage.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: An inconsistency in timestamps between events 1 and 2 was identified. It was resolved by assuming the events were listed in the correct order despite the slight discrepancy in times, allowing logical case grouping to proceed.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Event 15, the discharge of the 45-year-old male patient, was linked to Case 1 based on the completion of their ER path after a consultation and triage.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Lab test steps in Case 2 (events 8 and 10) and their alignment with subsequent consultations (event 11) were validated, ensuring the sequence matched typical ER workflows.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: It was hypothesized that Case 3's patient followed a Surgery-first workflow without ER triage, supported by their consistent association with Surgery-related events.
